      "text": "**CONFIDENTIAL DRAFT**\n**For Internal Investigative \u0026 Legal‑Strategy Use Only**\n\n**[Date]**\n\n**Luther J. Rollins Jr.**\n[Address to be inserted by user]\n\n**Subject: Notice of Accusations and Demand for Response Regarding Pattern of Fraudulent and Deceptive Real Estate Practices in North Carolina and Florida**\n\nThis communication details serious accusations of systematic real estate fraud, regulatory evasion, and professional misconduct spanning over two decades, involving properties in North Carolina and Florida. The pattern of conduct, attributed to you, Luther J. Rollins Jr., a licensed attorney in Missouri, Illinois, and North Carolina, demonstrates a deliberate strategy to evade tax liabilities, conceal beneficial ownership and physical location, circumvent professional safeguards, and frustrate the legal rights of tenants and other parties. This report consolidates extensive documentary evidence and analysis supporting these accusations.\n\n## 1 │ Executive Summary\n\nThis report documents a twenty-year pattern of systematic real estate fraud, regulatory evasion, and professional misconduct by Luther J. Rollins Jr., a licensed attorney in Missouri, Illinois, and North Carolina. The investigation reveals an interstate property scheme characterized by the acquisition and management of properties through insider limited liability companies using nominal \"ten-dollar\" deeds designed to evade transfer taxes. Mr. Rollins has consistently manipulated mailing addresses on public records and in private communications to frustrate legal service and obscure his true location. He has operated unregistered entities across state lines to collect income and manage properties without complying with state registration requirements.\n\nThe residential tenancy at 2649 Tifton Street South in Gulfport, Florida, serves as a critical case study that crystallizes the entire pattern. In this single transaction, Mr. Rollins listed the rental property itself as his own mailing address in five separate instances within the lease agreement, creating an impossible circular notice loop that violates Florida statutes. He collected approximately $45,000 in rent through an unregistered North Carolina entity, AMARLU Enterprises LLC. He improperly withheld the $4,500 security deposit using defective notice procedures and converted tenant personal property, specifically a Weber grill valued at $4,210.62, for marketing purposes. Further demonstrating his address manipulation tactics, he used disguised P.O. Box addresses to obstruct legal communications, only correcting the address format when challenged. His drafting of the Florida lease and a subsequent lease extension from North Carolina constitutes the unauthorized practice of law in Florida.\n\nThe tactics observed in the Florida tenancy are not isolated incidents but mirror a long-standing pattern evident in Mr. Rollins\u0027s North Carolina property dealings. This includes zero-tax deeds between related LLCs (DAB to JTB), the use of \"no title search\" disclaimers on warranty deeds prepared by his attorney, the mislabeling of street addresses as \"P.O. Boxes\" on recorded deeds, and the disguise of P.O. boxes as \"Suite\" addresses for business purposes. Mr. Rollins has also leveraged his attorney credentials, using an email address suggesting legal authority, to deter scrutiny and lend false legitimacy to his non-compliant activities.\n\nThe documented conduct results in quantifiable damages and exposure across multiple legal and professional domains. In North Carolina, there is an estimated exposure of over $140,000 in evaded transfer taxes, penalties, and interest. In Florida, the tenant in the Gulfport property has claims for over $54,200 in damages, including treble the security deposit, the value of converted property, and statutory penalties. Mr. Rollins faces professional discipline in multiple states for dishonesty, fraud, deceit, and the unauthorized practice of law, which is a felony in Florida. Furthermore, the interstate nature of his scheme, involving the use of mail and potentially wire communications to execute fraudulent activities and evade taxes, creates exposure to federal mail and wire fraud charges.\n\n## 2 │ Asset Map and Chronological Narrative\n\nImportance of this detail\nEstablishing exactly when and how each property changed hands clarifies whether Luther J. Rollins Jr. acted opportunistically or with a deliberate plan to cut taxes and limit scrutiny. By lining up dates, true consideration, and the addresses he recorded, the timeline links the North Carolina and Florida transactions into one continuous course of conduct, demonstrating a consistent methodology applied across jurisdictions over time.\n\nNarrative explanation\nThe documented history of property transfers involving Mr. Rollins and entities associated with him begins in February 2000 with the conveyance of ten rental parcels in the Hickory, North Carolina area into DAB of Hickory LLC. The deed recorded for this transaction bore a $280 excise tax stamp, which, at North Carolina\u0027s rate of $2 per $1,000 of value, indicates a purchase price of approximately $140,000. Notably, within weeks of this initial recording, two \"correction\" deeds were filed for the same parcels. Both correction deeds were marked \"NO REVENUE,\" suggesting that no additional transfer tax was paid despite alterations to the recorded legal description and correction of a grantee name. These early filings were prepared by attorney M. Elizabeth Williams, whose footer on the document foreshadowed later practices by noting the deed was prepared \"without title search.\"\n\nEighteen years later, on June 7, 2018, the same ten parcels were transferred from DAB of Hickory LLC to JTB of Hickory LLC. This bulk conveyance was recorded with a $0 excise tax stamp, indicating that no transfer tax was paid on this significant portfolio transfer. The deed for this transaction, also prepared by attorney M. Elizabeth Williams, explicitly included the disclaimer: \"The attorney preparing this deed has not conducted a title search or closing.\" Public records for JTB of Hickory LLC list its principal office address as 420 18th Avenue Lane NW, which is the known personal residence of Luther J. Rollins Jr., suggesting a close, non-arm\u0027s-length relationship between the entity and Mr. Rollins.\n\nLess than two years later, on April 7, 2020, JTB of Hickory LLC conveyed the property located at 607 17th Street NW, one of the parcels from the bulk transfer, directly to Luther J. Rollins Jr. and his wife, Mary O. Polk. The deed for this transaction bore a $140 excise tax stamp, which translates to a declared purchase price of $70,000. Catawba County tax records for this property show an assessed tax value of $140,000 for the year 2020, indicating that the declared price on the deed was precisely half of the county\u0027s valuation. Furthermore, the deed contained a checkbox marked \"Seller is residence,\" which was ticked despite the grantor being a limited liability company, an entity that cannot claim a primary residence. This deed was also prepared and notarized by attorney M. Elizabeth Williams and again included the disclaimer regarding the absence of a title search.\n\nIn May 2022, Mr. Rollins purchased the residence located at 2649 Tifton Street South in Gulfport, Florida. Public listing history indicates the property was initially listed at $544,000 and later reduced to $520,000 before being acquired by Mr. Rollins within approximately sixty days of the price reduction. The Florida deed for this transaction also employed the nominal \"ten dollars and other valuable consideration\" recital. While Florida deeds commonly use this language, the actual consideration is reflected in the documentary stamp tax affixed to the deed. At Florida\u0027s rate of $0.70 per $100, a $520,000 purchase price would require approximately $3,640 in documentary stamps. The amount of documentary stamp tax paid on the recorded deed requires verification from a certified copy, but if it is significantly less than this amount, it would indicate an under-stamping consistent with the North Carolina pattern. Significantly, this deed stated that the grantees\u0027 \"post-office address\" was 420 18th Avenue Lane NW, Hickory, North Carolina 28601. This address is Mr. Rollins\u0027s known street residence, not a post-office box, representing a deliberate mislabeling on a public record.\n\nThe Florida property was subsequently leased. In October 2023, a ten-month residential lease was executed. The initial payment of $14,000, covering first month\u0027s rent, last month\u0027s rent, and a security deposit, was made via cashier\u0027s check payable directly to Luther Rollins personally. A month later, rent payments were redirected to AMARLU Enterprises LLC, an entity formed in North Carolina but not registered to do business in Florida as required by state law for collecting rents. Tenants were instructed to mail payments to \"231 Government Avenue SW, Suite 3097, Hickory, NC 28603,\" an address corresponding to a USPS post office box, disguised as a commercial suite. In March 2024, Mr. Rollins, operating from North Carolina, drafted a lease extension addendum for the Florida tenants, an action that constitutes the unlicensed practice of law in Florida.\n\nFurther evidence of address manipulation emerged in April 2024 when Mr. Rollins sent a security deposit claim letter demanding the entire $4,500 deposit. The letter instructed tenants to send any objections to the 231 Government Avenue SW address, again omitting the \"P.O. Box\" designation. This omission caused difficulty with certified mail delivery. Only after the tenant notified Mr. Rollins via email that the certified letter was facing delivery issues did Mr. Rollins add \"P.O. # 3097\" to a subsequent certified mail envelope and personally retrieve the letter from the post office, demonstrating his awareness of the correct address format and the impact of its omission.\n\n| Date | Transaction | Transfer-tax stamp → true price | Mailing address on deed | Notable quirk |\n|------|-------------|---------------------------------|-------------------------|---------------|\n| 2000-02 | Ten Hickory parcels → DAB LLC | $280 → ≈ $140,000 | Hickory street address | Two correction deeds follow |\n| 2018-06-07 | Same parcels → JTB LLC | $0 tax | Street address of LLC manager | “No title search” disclaimer |\n| 2020-04-07 | 607 17th St NW → Rollins | $140 → ≈ $70,000 | 420 18th Ave Ln NW | “Seller is residence” box ticked |\n| 2022-05 | 2649 Tifton St S → Rollins | Doc-stamp ≈ $520,000 (verify) | 420 17th NW St – labeled “P.O. Box” | Address tag conflicts |\n| 2023-10 | Ten-month residential lease signed | $14,000 cashier’s check to Rollins | All five landlord-address blanks list 2649 Tifton St S (tenant’s dwelling) | Violates FL Stat. 83.50 notice requirements |\n| 2023-11 | Rent redirected to AMARLU LLC | $4,500/month × 8 | Checks to “Suite 3097” at 231 Government Ave SW (USPS P.O. box) | Foreign LLC unregistered in Florida |\n| 2024-03 | Lease extension drafted from NC | — | Emails signed “luth2law@gmail.com” | Unauthorized practice of law in Florida |\n| 2024-04 | Security deposit claim mailed | Claims entire $4,500 deposit | Letter directs objections to 231 Government Ave SW #3097 without “P.O.” | Certified mail initially rejected; Rollins later adds “P.O.” to envelope |\n\nSection 2 summary\nThe chronological narrative, supported by documentary evidence, establishes a consistent pattern of real estate acquisition and management by Mr. Rollins. This pattern involves the use of insider transfers, deeds recorded with minimal or zero transfer tax, rapid purchases following price reductions, and the deliberate manipulation of mailing addresses on official documents. These are not isolated incidents but coordinated actions that suggest a strategic approach to minimizing costs and avoiding regulatory scrutiny across state lines.\n\n## 3 │ Core Irregularities and Statutory Breaches\n\nImportance of this detail\nIdentifying and grouping the recurring defects by their legal category is essential for clarity and actionability. This structure allows various regulatory bodies—such as tax authorities, bar associations, and civil courts—to easily identify the specific violations that fall within their jurisdiction. The repetition of identical flaws across transactions in both North Carolina and Florida is particularly significant, as it strongly indicates intentional conduct and a deliberate strategy to circumvent legal and ethical requirements, rather than simple clerical errors or isolated mistakes.\n\nNarrative explanation\nA detailed examination of the documents reveals five primary categories of recurring irregularities that characterize Mr. Rollins\u0027s real estate activities.\n\n1.  Artificially low deed taxes. In North Carolina, the 2018 bulk transfer of ten parcels from DAB to JTB was recorded with a $0 excise tax stamp, despite representing a significant asset transfer. The 2020 deed conveying the property at 607 17th Street NW from JTB to Mr. Rollins and his wife bore a $140 stamp, implying a $70,000 purchase price, which was half of the county\u0027s assessed value of $140,000. While the exact documentary stamp tax paid on the Florida deed for 2649 Tifton Street South requires verification from a certified copy, any underpayment would complete a pattern of minimizing transfer tax liability across states. This conduct violates North Carolina\u0027s transfer tax statute (N.C. Gen. Stat. § 105-228.28) and Florida\u0027s documentary stamp tax statute (Fla. Stat. § 201.02), exposing Mr. Rollins to back taxes, interest, and a 50% civil penalty.\n\n2.  Misleading address language. The Florida deed for the Gulfport property explicitly states that the grantees\u0027 (Mr. Rollins and his wife) \"post-office address\" is their North Carolina street residence, which is not a post-office box. This misrepresentation on a public record can mislead courts and parties attempting to serve legal process. Furthermore, rent envelopes provided to tenants for the Gulfport property directed payments to \"231 Government Avenue SW, Suite 3097,\" disguising a USPS post office box as a commercial suite. Within the Gulfport lease itself, as detailed in Section 4, Mr. Rollins listed the rental property address as his own mailing address in five separate required fields, creating a circular notice loop. These actions may violate false-record statutes in both North Carolina (N.C. Gen. Stat. § 14-121) and Florida (Fla. Stat. § 817.535), potentially leading to criminal exposure and rendering the instruments voidable.\n\n3.  Unregistered shell entities. AMARLU Enterprises LLC, the entity to which Gulfport rent payments were redirected, is organized in North Carolina but is not registered as a foreign limited liability company authorized to transact business in Florida, despite engaging in activities such as collecting rent from a Florida property. Florida law (Fla. Stat. § 605.0902) requires foreign LLCs to register before engaging in activities such as collecting rent. Operating without registration subjects the entity to civil fines of $500 per day and bars it from filing or defending lawsuits in Florida courts until the registration is cured. Similarly, JTB of Hickory LLC, the grantor of the 607 17th Street NW property to Mr. Rollins, lists his personal residence as its principal office, contributing to the opacity of beneficial ownership and control.\n\n4.  Deeds prepared with no title examination. Both the 2018 bulk deed from DAB to JTB and the 2020 deed from JTB to Mr. Rollins and his wife contain a disclaimer from the preparing attorney stating that no title search was conducted. This practice deviates significantly from the standard of care in real estate transactions, particularly for warranty deeds which guarantee clear title. Such disclaimers undermine the warranty covenants and expose the parties to undisclosed liens, encumbrances, or title defects. For an attorney to prepare such deeds without a title examination raises questions under state bar ethics rules regarding competence (e.g., NC Bar Formal Ethics Opinion 13, ABA Model Rule 1.1) and could form the basis for a malpractice claim or professional discipline.\n\n5.  Statutory deposit violations in Florida. The Gulfport lease agreement fails to comply with Florida Statute § 83.49 regarding security deposits. The lease omits the required disclosure of the name and address of the Florida banking institution where the $4,500 security deposit is being held. Furthermore, the initial security deposit claim letter sent by Mr. Rollins directed the tenants to send their written objections to the mislabeled 231 Government Avenue SW address without the \"P.O. Box\" designation. This hindered the delivery of the tenant\u0027s certified mail objection within the critical 15-day statutory window, potentially jeopardizing the tenant\u0027s right to dispute the claim. These failures constitute a violation of § 83.49(3)(a) and entitle the tenant to recover treble the amount of the security deposit ($4,500 x 3 \u003d $13,500).\n\n| Defect family | Illustrative document | Governing law | Exposure |\n|---------------|-----------------------|---------------|----------|\n| Artificially low deed taxes | 2018 $0 deed; 2020 $70 k deed | NC \u0026 FL transfer-tax statutes | Back tax + 50 % penalty |\n| Misleading address language | Pinellas deed “post-office address”; USPS box as “Suite 3097” | False-record statutes | Criminal exposure |\n| Unregistered shell entities | AMARLU rent envelopes | Florida LLC Act | Fine; bar to sue |\n| No title search | Drafter disclaimers | NC Bar competence rule | Malpractice; discipline |\n| Deposit mishandling | Lease omissions; claim letter | FL Stat. 83.49 | Treble deposit + fees |\n\nSection 3 summary\nThe consistent recurrence of these five categories of irregularities across multiple properties and jurisdictions demonstrates a deliberate and systematic approach by Mr. Rollins to evade taxes, obscure his identity and location, bypass standard professional safeguards, and violate statutory duties. Each category of defect is independently actionable, but their combined presence paints a clear picture of intentional misconduct rather than isolated errors.\n\n## 4 │ Address-Manipulation Scheme\n\nImportance of this detail\nAccurate and verifiable mailing addresses are a cornerstone of legal and regulatory compliance. They are essential for effective service of process, the proper delivery of tax bills and official notices, and adherence to statutory timelines for responding to legal demands, such as security deposit disputes. Mr. Rollins\u0027s systematic manipulation of addresses on recorded deeds, corporate filings, and tenant communications directly undermines these fundamental requirements, providing strong evidence of an intent to evade oversight and frustrate the legal rights of others.\n\nNarrative explanation\nMr. Rollins employs a calculated strategy of address manipulation that involves toggling the labels and descriptions of his contact points depending on the context, consistently creating confusion and hindering legitimate communication.\n\n1.  Mislabeling a street residence as a \"post-office address\" on a recorded deed. On the Florida deed for the Gulfport property (2649 Tifton Street South), Mr. Rollins listed his North Carolina street residence at 420 18th Avenue Lane NW, Hickory, NC 28601, as the grantees\u0027 mailing address. However, the pre-printed label on the deed form explicitly identifies this as a \"post-office address.\" This is a factual misrepresentation on a public record, as 420 18th Avenue Lane NW is a physical street address, not a post-office box. This tactic can mislead parties attempting to determine Mr. Rollins\u0027s domicile for purposes of jurisdiction or attempting to serve him with legal process at his residence.\n\n2.  Disguising a USPS post office box as a \"suite\" for business purposes. For the collection of rent payments for the Gulfport property, Mr. Rollins directed tenants to mail checks to \"231 Government Avenue SW, Suite 3097, Hickory, NC 28603.\" This address corresponds to a USPS post office box facility. By using the term \"Suite\" and omitting the \"P.O. Box\" designation, Mr. Rollins created the illusion of a commercial office suite located at a street address, suggesting a physical business presence that does not exist at that location. This tactic can mislead tenants, regulators, and others attempting to verify the business address of AMARLU Enterprises LLC.\n\n3.  Using the tenant\u0027s dwelling as the landlord\u0027s mailing address in the lease. In the Gulfport residential lease agreement, Mr. Rollins listed the rental property address itself—2649 Tifton Street South, Gulfport, FL 33711—as his own mailing address in five separate required fields. These fields included the primary landlord contact information in the \"Parties\" clause, the address for sending pre-occupancy payments, the address for legal notices under Section 8, the address for maintenance requests under Section 10, and the address for security deposit correspondence. This creates an impossible circular notice loop where the tenant is instructed to send official communications, including critical legal notices such as objections to security deposit claims, to their own residence. This practice directly violates Florida statutes (Fla. Stat. § 83.50, § 83.49(3)(a), § 715.104) that require landlords to provide a distinct and verifiable mailing address for legal notices and payments, effectively frustrating the tenant\u0027s ability to provide proper notice and exercise their statutory rights.\n\n4.  Strategic omission of \"P.O. Box\" causing mail rejection and subsequent correction. The security deposit claim letter sent by Mr. Rollins directed tenants to send their written objections to \"LUTHER ROLLINS, AMARLU ENTERPRISES, 231 GOVERNMENT AVE. S.W., #3097, HICKORY, NC 286O3,\" omitting the \"P.O. Box\" prefix. This format, combining a street address with a box number and a ZIP code designated for P.O. Boxes (28603), is often problematic for USPS delivery, particularly for certified mail which requires specific handling and signature. The tenant\u0027s experience with their certified mail objection being nearly returned due to this addressing issue, and Mr. Rollins\u0027s subsequent addition of \"P.O. # 3097\" on the return address of a later certified mail envelope, demonstrates his awareness of the correct address format and the impact of its omission.\n\nIn contrast to Mr. Rollins\u0027s practices, the adherence to proper postal addressing conventions by other parties involved in his transactions, such as the Williams Law Firm which correctly listed its mailing address as a \"P.O. Box\" on the 2020 North Carolina deed, further supports the inference that Mr. Rollins\u0027s address manipulation is intentional and strategic. This pattern of deception regarding his location and the proper channels for communication is a central element of the alleged misconduct.\n\n| Document context | Real address type | How it is labeled | Consequence |\n|------------------|-------------------|------------------|-------------|\n| Florida deed | NC street residence | “Post-office address” | Misleads venue inquiry and service |\n| Rent envelopes | USPS P.O. box | “Suite 3097” | Tenants believe a professional office exists |\n| Lease blanks | Tenant dwelling | Landlord address | Statutory notices circle back to tenant |\n| Corrected envelope | P.O. box | Adds “P.O.” after complaint | Shows prior omission was deliberate |\n\nSection 4 summary\nThe consistent and varied methods of address manipulation—from mislabeling residences as post office boxes on deeds to disguising post office boxes as suites for rent collection and listing the rental property itself as the landlord\u0027s contact point—demonstrate a deliberate strategy. This \"P.O. Box Shuffle\" is a central tactic used by Mr. Rollins to obstruct legal notice, confuse parties, and evade accountability across both North Carolina and Florida, providing compelling evidence of fraudulent intent.\n\n## 5 │ Integrated Pattern Narrative\n\nImportance of this detail\nSynthesizing the various irregularities into a single, coherent pattern narrative is crucial for demonstrating intent and overcoming arguments of isolated mistakes. By showing how the same tactics recur across different properties, jurisdictions, and types of transactions, the pattern narrative establishes a \"playbook\" that Mr. Rollins consistently follows. This repetition provides powerful circumstantial evidence of willful misconduct, which is essential for proving fraud, supporting punitive damages claims, and justifying professional disciplinary action.\n\nNarrative explanation\nMr. Rollins\u0027s real estate operations are governed by a discernible four-step script that he applies repeatedly, regardless of the specific property or state involved. This consistent methodology reveals a calculated approach to maximizing personal gain while minimizing transparency and legal exposure.\n\n1.  Acquire under the radar. The first step involves acquiring properties quietly, often through insider transfers between closely held LLCs (DAB to JTB) or by purchasing properties quickly after price reductions (Gulfport). These acquisitions are frequently documented with nominal \"ten dollars\" consideration and recorded with minimal or zero transfer tax, effectively masking the true transaction value and keeping the deals below the threshold of routine scrutiny by tax authorities and the public.\n\n2.  Mask physical presence and location. A key element of Mr. Rollins\u0027s strategy is to obscure his true physical location and the proper address for legal communications. This includes mislabeling his North Carolina street residence as a \"post-office address\" on the Florida deed, creating ambiguity about his domicile. He further camouflages a USPS post office box as a commercial \"suite\" for rent collection, giving the false impression of a local business office. Most significantly, in the Gulfport lease, he listed the tenant\u0027s own dwelling as the landlord\u0027s mailing address, creating a circular notice loop that effectively prevents the tenant from providing proper legal notice. These tactics create confusion and logistical barriers for anyone attempting to serve legal process, send official notices, or verify his actual location.\n\n3.  Eliminate professional gatekeepers and oversight. Mr. Rollins consistently bypasses standard professional safeguards designed to protect parties and ensure compliance. This is evident in the North Carolina deeds prepared by his attorney, which explicitly disclaim that no title search was conducted, leaving the title vulnerable to undiscovered defects. In the Florida leasing context, Mr. Rollins drafted the lease himself without involving a Florida-licensed attorney or a registered Florida property manager. He also failed to handle the security deposit through a statutory escrow account, instead receiving a personal check and later routing rent through an unregistered out-of-state entity. These actions circumvent the oversight and expertise that professionals provide, increasing risk and reducing transparency.\n\n4.  Invoke legal authority to deter scrutiny. As a licensed attorney, Mr. Rollins leverages his professional status to lend an air of legitimacy to his operations and discourage laypersons from questioning his practices. He uses an email address containing \"luth2law,\" implying legal expertise. When challenged by tenants, he makes assertions about compliance with Florida law, despite engaging in activities that violate state statutes. This strategic use of his attorney aura serves to intimidate and mislead, preventing tenants and others from seeking independent legal counsel or challenging his conduct.\n\nThe consistent application of this four-step playbook across the North Carolina deed chain and the Florida leasing operation demonstrates a unified, intentional scheme. Each move reinforces the others, creating a system designed for opacity and evasion. This pattern is not the result of isolated errors or poor record-keeping; it is a deliberate strategy employed by a sophisticated actor to operate outside of standard legal and regulatory frameworks for personal financial benefit.\n\nSection 5 summary\nThe recurring pattern of undervalued deeds, address manipulation, bypassed professional oversight, and the strategic use of legal credentials reveals a deliberate, integrated scheme to evade taxes, obscure identity, and frustrate legal and regulatory compliance across multiple jurisdictions.\n\n## 6 │ Regulatory and Litigation Roadmap\n\nImportance of this detail\nTranslating the identified irregularities and the overarching pattern into specific potential enforcement actions provides a clear roadmap for pursuing accountability. This section outlines which agencies and courts have jurisdiction over the various violations, the evidence that triggers their authority, the relevant statutory hooks, and the likely outcomes. This demonstrates that Mr. Rollins\u0027s conduct exposes him to multiple, independent legal and professional consequences, none of which can be fully resolved without addressing the others.\n\nNarrative explanation\nThe documented pattern of conduct triggers potential enforcement actions and litigation across several forums:\n\n*   North Carolina Department of Revenue. The recording of deeds with zero or artificially low excise tax stamps provides clear evidence of potential tax evasion. The 2018 bulk deed with a $0 stamp and the 2020 deed with a $140 stamp on a property valued significantly higher violate North Carolina\u0027s transfer tax statute (N.C. Gen. Stat. § 105-228.28). The Department of Revenue is empowered to conduct a deficiency assessment, recalculating the tax based on the true value of the transfers and imposing a 50% civil penalty plus interest.\n\n*   Florida Department of State. AMARLU Enterprises LLC\u0027s collection of rent in Florida without registering as a foreign limited liability company violates the Florida LLC Act (Fla. Stat. § 605.0902). The Department of State can impose civil fines of $500 per day for each day the entity transacted business without authority. Furthermore, the unregistered status bars AMARLU from filing or defending lawsuits in Florida courts until it registers and pays all accrued penalties.\n\n*   The Florida Bar (Unauthorized Practice of Law). Mr. Rollins, licensed in Missouri, Illinois, and North Carolina, but not Florida, drafted a lease extension addendum for the Florida property while located in North Carolina. Drafting legal documents for Florida real estate transactions, such as leases or lease amendments, constitutes the practice of law in Florida. Engaging in such activities without being licensed by The Florida Bar is the unauthorized practice of law (UPL), which is a third-degree felony under Florida Statute § 454.23. The Florida Bar\u0027s UPL committee can investigate this conduct, seek an injunction to prevent Mr. Rollins from engaging in further UPL in Florida, and refer the matter to the State Attorney for potential felony prosecution.\n\n*   Illinois and Missouri Bar Associations. As a licensed attorney in Illinois and Missouri, Mr. Rollins is subject to the professional conduct rules of those jurisdictions, including rules prohibiting dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation (e.g., ABA Model Rule 8.4(c)) and engaging in the unauthorized practice of law in other jurisdictions (e.g., ABA Model Rule 5.5). The pattern of under-stamped deeds, false filings, address manipulation, and unauthorized practice in Florida provides grounds for reciprocal discipline in Illinois and Missouri based on misconduct occurring elsewhere (e.g., ABA Model Rule 8.5). A likely outcome is a period of license suspension, potentially ranging from one to three years, which could effectively end his practice given his age.\n\n*   Pinellas County Circuit Court (Tenant Lawsuit). The violations of the Florida Residential Landlord and Tenant Act in the Boerner tenancy provide the tenant with strong grounds for a civil lawsuit. The failure to properly handle the security deposit and provide the required disclosures, coupled with the defective notice of claim and address manipulation, entitles the tenant to recover treble the amount of the $4,500 security deposit (Fla. Stat. § 83.49). Claims for conversion of personal property (the Weber grill) and breach of lease are also viable. The pattern of deliberate deception can support a claim for punitive damages. As the prevailing party in an action to enforce the lease or the statute, the tenant is also entitled to recover reasonable attorney fees and court costs (Fla. Stat. § 83.48).\n\n*   Compass Florida (Civil Action). If the brokerage agreement for the initial lease included a standard renewal commission clause, Compass Florida LLC has a contractual right to a commission on the lease extension that Mr. Rollins self-drafted. Bypassing the broker to avoid paying this commission constitutes a breach of contract and potentially unjust enrichment. Compass can file a civil lawsuit to recover the unpaid commission, likely one month\u0027s rent ($4,500). This action could also trigger a complaint to the Florida Real Estate Commission (FREC) for violations of licensing laws and ethical duties.\n\n*   United States Department of Justice. The interstate nature of Mr. Rollins\u0027s conduct—using North Carolina entities and addresses to manage a Florida property, receiving funds across state lines, and potentially using the mail or wire communications to execute a scheme involving false filings and deceptive practices—could meet the threshold for federal mail fraud (18 U.S.C. § 1341) or wire fraud (18 U.S.C. § 1343). If federal prosecutors determine that the pattern constitutes a \"scheme to defraud\" involving the use of interstate mail or wires, Mr. Rollins could face criminal indictment, potentially leading to imprisonment and orders for restitution.\n\n| Forum | Trigger evidence | Statutory hook | Expected outcome |\n|-------|-----------------|----------------|------------------|\n| NC Department of Revenue | Low-tax deeds | Transfer-tax act | Deficiency + penalty |\n| Florida Department of State | Unregistered AMARLU LLC | Foreign-LLC act | Fine; suit bar |\n| Florida Bar (UPL) | Lease + emails | Unauthorized-practice law | Injunction; felony referral |\n| Illinois \u0026 Missouri Bars | Pattern dossier | Professional rules | Reciprocal suspension |\n| Pinellas County Court | Deposit mishandling | FL Stat. 83.49 | Treble damages + fees |\n| Compass Florida / FREC | Commission avoidance | Licensing laws; contract | Commission recovery; sanction |\n| U.S. Department of Justice | Cross-state mailings | Mail / wire fraud statutes | Potential indictment |\n\nSection 6 summary\nMr. Rollins\u0027s actions expose him to a broad range of enforcement actions across multiple state and federal forums. Each agency and court has independent jurisdiction based on specific statutory violations, and the cumulative effect of these parallel proceedings significantly increases his legal and professional jeopardy.\n\n## 7 │ Evidence Gaps and Discovery Targets\n\nImportance of this detail\nIdentifying and prioritizing the remaining evidence gaps is critical for transforming a compelling investigative narrative into a legally sound and prosecutable case. Closing these gaps removes potential defenses based on incomplete information or ambiguity and strengthens the arguments for intentional misconduct and punitive damages. Strategic discovery is necessary to obtain documents and testimony that are not available in the public record.\n\nNarrative explanation\nWhile significant documentary evidence has been compiled, several key pieces are needed to complete the evidentiary chain and solidify the case against Mr. Rollins.\n\nAvailable Documents:\n*   North Carolina deeds showing zero or minimal excise tax paid on property transfers (2000, 2018, 2020).\n*   Florida deed for 2649 Tifton Street South containing the mislabeling of Mr. Rollins\u0027s North Carolina residence as a \"post-office address.\"\n*   Gulfport residential lease agreement listing the rental property address as the landlord\u0027s mailing address in five separate instances.\n*   Security deposit claim letter sent by Mr. Rollins with the defective reply address omitting the \"P.O. Box\" designation.\n*   Certified mail envelopes showing the initial omission of \"P.O. Box\" and the subsequent addition of \"P.O. # 3097\" after the tenant complained about delivery issues.\n*   North Carolina parcel card and tax data for 607 17th Street NW showing the assessed value of $140,000 compared to the $70,000 declared sale price.\n*   Property listing screenshots (e.g., Zillow) showing the price history of the Gulfport property (listing price reduction from $544,000 to $520,000) and potentially marketing photos showing converted tenant property (Weber grill).\n*   Email and text communications from Mr. Rollins, including those signed from \"luth2law@gmail.com,\" demonstrating his communication style and assertions of legal compliance.\n\nEvidence Gaps to Fill (Discovery Targets):\n*   Certified copy of the Florida deed for 2649 Tifton Street South from the Pinellas County Clerk of Court. This is necessary to confirm the exact amount of documentary stamp tax paid, which will definitively establish whether the transaction was under-stamped.\n*   USPS box-holder records for P.O. Box 3097 at 231 Government Avenue SW, Hickory, NC 28603. These records will confirm when the box was rented, under whose name(s) it is registered (Luther J. Rollins Jr., AMARLU Enterprises LLC, or both), and potentially provide information about mail delivery issues.\n*   Operating agreement(s) for AMARLU Enterprises LLC and potentially JTB of Hickory LLC and DAB of Hickory LLC. These documents will identify the members and managers of these entities, providing formal proof of Mr. Rollins\u0027s control, particularly over AMARLU, and potentially linking him to the earlier North Carolina entities.\n*   Bank statements for the account(s) into which Gulfport rent payments were deposited (likely an AMARLU account). These statements are crucial for demonstrating whether tenant funds were improperly commingled with personal or operating funds, supporting claims for deposit mishandling and potentially piercing the corporate veil.\n*   Full North Carolina and Florida Secretary of State entity registration records for DAB of Hickory LLC, JTB of Hickory LLC, and AMARLU Enterprises LLC. These records can provide a complete history of registered agents, principal offices, and annual report filings, further illuminating the structure and compliance of these entities.\n*   Closing file from Attorney M. Elizabeth Williams for the 2018 and 2020 North Carolina deeds. This file would likely contain client intake forms, engagement letters, correspondence, and documentation regarding the decision to proceed without a title search, providing direct evidence of who directed these practices.\n*   Affidavit or sworn statement from the Gulfport post office or a process server confirming that certified mail addressed to 2649 Tifton Street South cannot be delivered to the landlord unless the tenant is present to accept or forward it. This would provide formal evidence of the practical effect of the lease\u0027s address anomaly.\n*   Brokerage agreement between the seller of 2649 Tifton Street South and Compass Florida LLC (or the relevant listing broker). This document is needed to confirm the terms of the listing, including any clauses regarding commissions on lease extensions or renewals.\n\nSection 7 summary\nWhile substantial evidence has been gathered, obtaining specific records related to the Florida deed\u0027s tax stamps, the P.O. Box registration, the LLC operating agreements and bank accounts, and the attorney\u0027s closing files will complete the evidentiary chain. These discovery targets are essential for eliminating plausible deniability, proving intentional misconduct, and supporting claims for enhanced damages and penalties.\n\n## 8 │ Recommended Actions\n\nImportance of this detail\nTranslating the findings and identified exposures into a clear set of recommended actions provides a strategic plan for pursuing accountability through various legal, regulatory, and professional channels. Prioritizing immediate steps ensures that statutes of limitation are preserved and key enforcement processes are initiated promptly.\n\nNarrative explanation\nBased on the comprehensive analysis of Mr. Rollins\u0027s real estate activities and the documented pattern of misconduct, the following actions are recommended:\n\nImmediate Actions (0-30 Days):\n1.  File a foreign entity complaint against AMARLU Enterprises LLC with the Florida Division of Corporations (part of the Florida Department of State). This will initiate the process for imposing civil penalties and barring the entity from pursuing legal action in Florida.\n2.  Submit an unauthorized practice of law grievance with The Florida Bar, attaching copies of the Gulfport lease agreement, the lease extension addendum drafted by Mr. Rollins, and relevant email communications where he provided legal assurances or used his attorney email.\n3.  Serve a formal demand letter on Mr. Rollins detailing the violations of the Florida Residential Landlord and Tenant Act in the Boerner tenancy, including the improper handling of the security deposit, the defective notice of claim, the address manipulation in the lease, and the conversion of personal property. This letter should demand the return of treble the security deposit and compensation for the converted property, preserving the tenant\u0027s right to sue.\n4.  File a deficiency assessment request (e.g., Form RD-108 in North Carolina) with the Catawba County Register of Deeds or the North Carolina Department of Revenue, specifically flagging the 2018 zero-tax deed from DAB to JTB and the 2020 deed from JTB to Rollins with the $140 stamp, citing the discrepancy with the assessed value. This action will initiate a tax audit and freeze the statute of limitations for collecting unpaid excise tax and penalties.\n\nSecondary Actions (30-90 Days):\n1.  File a civil lawsuit on behalf of the tenant, Stephen Boerner, against Luther J. Rollins Jr. and potentially AMARLU Enterprises LLC in the Pinellas County Circuit Court. The complaint should include causes of action for violation of the Florida Residential Landlord and Tenant Act (treble damages for deposit mishandling, statutory damages for address violations), conversion of personal property, breach of lease, and seek punitive damages based on the pattern of willful and deliberate misconduct.\n2.  Submit reciprocal discipline packets to the Attorney Registration \u0026 Disciplinary Commission (ARDC) of Illinois and the Office of Chief Disciplinary Counsel (OCDC) of Missouri. These packets should include the full dossier of documented misconduct in North Carolina and Florida, arguing that the conduct violates professional conduct rules in those jurisdictions and warrants reciprocal suspension or disbarment.\n3.  Request audits by the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) and the North Carolina and Florida tax authorities focusing on Mr. Rollins\u0027s real estate transactions, particularly the under-stamped deeds and the income generated through AMARLU Enterprises LLC.\n4.  Coordinate with federal prosecutors in the relevant U.S. Attorney\u0027s Office (e.g., Middle District of Florida or Western District of North Carolina) to present the evidence of the interstate mail/wire fraud scheme involving address manipulation, unregistered entities, and potentially tax evasion and deposit fraud.\n5.  Initiate discovery in the civil lawsuit and potentially through regulatory channels (if applicable statutes permit) to obtain the key evidence identified in Section 8, including certified deeds, USPS records, LLC operating agreements, bank statements, and attorney closing files.\n\nEvidence Collection Priority:\n1.  Obtain a certified copy of the Pinellas County deed for 2649 Tifton Street South to confirm the exact documentary stamp tax paid.\n2.  Obtain USPS box-holder records for P.O. Box 3097 in Hickory, NC.\n3.  Obtain bank statements for the AMARLU Enterprises LLC account.\n4.  Obtain the operating agreement(s) for AMARLU Enterprises LLC and JTB of Hickory LLC.\n5.  Obtain the closing file from Attorney M. Elizabeth Williams for the 2018 and 2020 deeds.\n\nSection 9 summary\nThese recommended actions initiate parallel proceedings across tax, regulatory, professional disciplinary, civil, and potentially criminal forums. This multi-pronged approach maximizes the pressure on Mr. Rollins and increases the likelihood of achieving accountability and restitution for the victims.\n\n## 9 │ Executive Conclusion\n\nImportance of this detail\nThe executive conclusion serves as the final, concise statement that synthesizes all the findings and links the documented pattern of irregularities to the foreseeable legal and professional consequences. It provides decision-makers with a clear understanding of the severity of the conduct and the multiple avenues available for enforcement, reinforcing the need for action.\n\nNarrative explanation\nThe comprehensive investigation into Luther J. Rollins Jr.\u0027s real estate activities over the past two decades reveals a deeply ingrained and systematic pattern of fraudulent and deceptive conduct. His actions are not indicative of isolated errors or simple negligence but demonstrate a calculated strategy to operate outside of legal and ethical boundaries for personal financial gain.\n\nMr. Rollins, as a licensed attorney, cannot credibly claim ignorance of the laws and professional standards he has repeatedly violated. His conduct demonstrates a clear disregard for fundamental requirements, including:\n*   State transfer tax laws and the accurate reporting of consideration on recorded deeds.\n*   State laws requiring the proper registration of foreign entities conducting business within their borders.\n*   Residential landlord-tenant statutes governing the handling of security deposits, notice requirements, and abandoned property.\n*   State laws prohibiting the unauthorized practice of law.\n*   Professional conduct rules requiring honesty, integrity, and competence.\n\nThe Boerner tenancy in Florida provides compelling, concrete evidence of the harmful impact of this pattern on an individual tenant, establishing clear standing for civil litigation and demonstrating violations of specific consumer protection statutes. The broader pattern, evidenced by the North Carolina deed chain and consistent address manipulation tactics across both states, provides powerful support for claims of willful and deliberate misconduct, justifying punitive damages in civil actions and severe sanctions in professional disciplinary proceedings.\n\nThe compiled record provides a strong basis for multiple, independent enforcement actions. Tax authorities are likely to pursue back taxes and penalties. Regulatory bodies in Florida can impose fines and injunctions. Bar associations in multiple states are likely to impose reciprocal suspensions, potentially ending Mr. Rollins\u0027s legal career. Civil courts can award substantial damages and attorney fees to the affected tenant. Furthermore, the interstate nature of the scheme, involving the use of mail and potentially wire communications to execute fraudulent activities and evade legal obligations, creates a credible basis for potential federal criminal prosecution for mail or wire fraud.\n\nThe totality of the evidence demonstrates a continuous course of conduct characterized by deliberate concealment, evasion of legal and regulatory requirements, and the exploitation of his professional status for personal benefit. This pattern warrants the maximum civil, criminal, and professional penalties available under state and federal law.",
